tips.004: You can farm certain crops like silkweed or cotton for a steady supply of thread fiber.
tips.008: The weaver can craft weather-specific clothing or new uniforms that increases the effectiveness of your workers.
tips.010: Shepherds will automatically find the first two animals to start a pasture.
tips.017: Don't want your hearthlings to leave town? The Engineer can make locks for doors.
tips.020: Trappers can set traps anywhere, but wilder areas with vegetation and no signs of civilization will always be better.
tips.022: Mining dirt will occasionally yield clay, stone, and rarities like bones.
tips.024: Need a starting food source? Look for fruit bushes or edible fungi and move them closer to you!
tips.029: Pasture animals will always go for pasture beds when the weather is bad for them. Place these under a roof to protect them!
tips.030: With a feeding manger you can make sure your pasture animals always have enough fodder available to them.
tips.031: Pets will try to sleep on the pet bed that is closest to their owner's bed. Keep a food bowl nearby for even more comfort.
tips.032: Fodder is enough to keep an animal healthy but only specific foods will increase the quality of animal products.
tips.033: You can determine a desirable amount of animals to keep in a pasture. They will be automatically slaughtered beyond this number.
tips.034: You can rename animals in a pasture and shepherds will try to avoid automatically slaughtering named creatures.
tips.035: Farmer crops have different and specific needs. You can find out about them by hovering your mouse over all the icons on the Farm Plot window!
tips.036: Different weathers and different biomes have dynamic values for humidity and sunlight. Try to optimize your farms as much as you can!
tips.037: Sunlight is very important for most farmer crops. Buildings and obstacles that obstruct the sun on the east-west axis will also affect it!
tips.038: Humidity is very important for many farmer crops, although some of them can thrive with little or no water at all!
tips.039: Although uncommon, a farmer crop might require water in specific amounts or ways to grow. For example, Paddy requires the Farm Plot to be flooded.
tips.040: No water isn't optimal for farmer crops, but excessive water might not be good either. Make sure to always check the Farm Plot window!
tips.041: Fertilizers can be created by the Herbalist and are very efficient in increasing the quality of farmer crops.
tips.042: Utilizing high quality resources and materials will yield higher quality products that are worth more and are more appealing.
tips.043: New workers are equipped with a set of Bronze Tools that can be replaced for faster and more efficient Iron and Steel tools made by the Blacksmith.
tips.044: Chopping firewood is an easy and reliable source of fuel until you can produce charcoal or mine coal.
tips.045: Harvesting fungi will destroy the wild spawn, maintaining a steady production of fungi requires the expertise of a dwarven Grower...
tips.046: The Herbalist is able to produce Farmer Seeds of most plants and trees from the region you are settling on.
tips.047: Different cold weathers will have different levels of cold. Blizzards can be very dangerous but fires and specific clothing can ease the effects.
tips.048: Hearthlings that go into the water on chilly, cold or freezing days will be hurt by the freezing waters.
tips.049: Hearthlings that go into the water on hot days will be refreshed for a while. Bath time!
tips.050: Be wary of wild animal dens and caves when settling. Wild wolves or bears aren't really strong but can cause trouble early on.
tips.051: Always make sure to keep a varied and hearty diet for your hearthlings. Many of them can have specific food preferences, intolerances, or tastes.
tips.052: Mega Crops have varied and unique rewards from each kind of crop.
tips.053: Hearthlings will prefer to wear warm clothing over clothing that provides bonuses during the autumn and winter.
tips.054: Having a good fuel stockpile with different grades and types will allow your crafters to optimize your production lines.
tips.055: Firewood, Charcoal, and Coke are examples of crafted fuels that will turn a single unit of fuel into multiple units.
tips.056: An enhanced anvil or furnace can replace your older ones in all functions and will allow you to smelt metals more efficiently.
tips.057: Hard Coal can be found in coal veins. Mining and trading are the only ways to acquire it!
tips.058: Carpenters can carve beautiful furniture out of those pesky fallen logs lying around!
tips.059: Masons can sculpt awesome statues out of the otherwise boring marble boulders!
tips.060: Different weapons and armor have additional advantages and disadvantages beyond their damage and protection values. Read all the tooltips!
tips.061: Short Swords are often considered a knight's sidearm and will provide no benefits other than a free hand for a trustworthy shield.
tips.062: Maces and hammers are efficient knight's weapons that will crush the armor of their target, exposing enemies to more allied damage.
tips.063: Polearms, like spears and halberds, are usually used by knights and are really good at putting fear in the hearts of enemy crowds at the cost of less protection.
tips.064: Long swords are versatile slashing weapons and can be used by footmen to hinder the mobility of enemies.
tips.065: Axes and other lighter, hacking weapons can be utilized by footmen for increased armor penetration against enemies.
tips.066: Two-handed weapons are extremely strong and powerful pieces of equipment, possessing a higher base damage and inflicting wounds that hurt enemies over time.
tips.067: Bows and Crossbows are both efficient ranged weapons. Bows can be faster but crossbows are often stronger, especially against armor.
tips.068: Light and medium armor can be worn by footmen while heavy armor is usually restricted to knights. The more armored a hearthling is, the braver they will be!
tips.069: You can switch what kind of equipment a soldier will prefer by using the toggle button in their unit frame.
tips.070: Weapons can get titles and renown over time, depending on the feats of their users. A titled weapon can be freely renamed by the player.
tips.071: Hearthlings can gain different titles during the course of their lives, depending on what amazing feats they achieve!
tips.072: Many wild animals can provide some sort of interesting resource or benefit to the wary player that explores their surroundings.
tips.073: You can sometimes find ore while mining common rock but the most reliable source of ore is mining veins themselves.
tips.074: Algae have some culinary uses but can also be dried and used as an herb by the Herbalist.
tips.075: Wondering what something is? If an object or creature has an information icon next to their name, click it to learn more!
tips.076: Any lower-grade fuel can be used to light the hearth, including peat or brown coal.
tips.077: Thatching material can be easily found if you harvest grassy plants like shrubs, or simply dig the grass layer.
tips.078: Trapping zones for big game might, although rarely, attract bears and other larger wild animals.
tips.079: Firewood holders and sheds are very efficient ways of storing fuel.
tips.080: Ball Clay can be easily found in large mining deposits, or boulders, at the bottom of water bodies like lakes.
tips.081: Hot meals and beverages like tea, stews and soups will provide hearthlings with a bonus that protects them from cold weather for some time.
tips.082: Cold or refreshing meals and beverages like juices or yogurt will provide hearthlings with a bonus that protects them from hot weather for some time.
tips.083: The Herbalist is capable of creating Farmer Seeds of most of the crops known to your kingdom. Trade away!
tips.084: You can hold the SHIFT key when clicking the 'Craft!' button to send that recipe straight to the top of the queue!
tips.085: Drinks can boost your citizens with several different effects. Make sure to check them out!
tips.086: If you can't provide your hearthlings with prepared drinks yet, make sure to at least build them a water well.
tips.087: Thirst will not hurt your citizens. Just their feelings!
tips.088: Make sure to always offer alternatives to alcoholic drinks. No one wants all their citizens being excessively merry all day long!
tips.089: Hearthlings will always prefer a drink that is more appropriate to the current time of the day, except when they really love something else.
tips.090: Tea will greatly boost the qualities of all crafted products although it also makes crafting a bit slower. Balance requires patience!
tips.091: Poisons and Toxins? Poisons last a long time and will slowly chip health away; Toxins disappear quickly but have more immediate effects.
tips.092: Drinks like milk or juices are considered simple while more complex, flavorful brewings like spirits or beer are considered prepared.
tips.093: Chitin armor can be crafted by the Weaver and will protect a lower level Footman against simple poisons and toxins.
tips.094: Sleeping is important! Make sure to provide comfortable bedrooms and personally assigned beds for your hearthlings.
tips.095: Dreaming of sheep rave parties? Click on your hearthlings while they're sleeping to see if they're having good or bad dreams...
tips.096: Fruit and nut trees take a long time to mature but will bear their produce even when small. The longer they grow, the better their yield will be.
tips.097: If starting during the Autumn, look around. There might be some extra food sources like nut trees before the winter!
tips.098: You can temporarily pause a crafter queue by clicking the 'Open' sign on the top right of the crafting screen.
tips.099: Crafted Bee Skeps require Captive Bees before they can work. Cut some trees and you might find a nest or two lying around!
